message.content: This question requires an understanding of Newton's Third Law of Motion, which states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. When Tom and Bill push on the large plastic ball from opposite sides with the same muscle power, their forces cancel each other out. Therefore, the ball stays in one place. Option (A) is subjective and not related to the principles of physics. Option (B) is incorrect because the ball is described as being made of plastic, not iron. Option (D) is extraneous information that does not affect the answer.

This question requires an understanding of Newton's third law of motion and how forces interact with objects. When Tom and Bill are pushing on the ball from opposite sides with the same amount of force, their forces cancel each other out, resulting in a net force of zero. This causes the ball to stay in one place and not move. Option (A) is incorrect because the ball does not possess human characteristics like being stubborn. Option (B) is incorrect because the ball being large and made of iron does not directly explain why it stays in one place. Option (D) is incorrect because the size of the ball does not determine whether it will move or not; it depends on the forces applied to it.

This question requires some basic understanding of Newton's Third Law of Motion, which states that for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. In this case, when Tom and Bill push on the ball with equal force from opposite sides, their forces cancel each other out, resulting in the ball staying in one place. Option (A) is incorrect because objects, like balls, do not have the ability to be stubborn. Option (B) is incorrect because the material the ball is made of is not given and it is not relevant to the question. Option (D) is incorrect because the size of the ball does not affect its ability to stay in one place when equal forces are being applied to it.

Option (B) is incorrect because the material of the ball and its size are not mentioned to be relevant factors. Option (D) is incorrect because the size of the ball is not relevant in this situation.

Option (A) is an anthropomorphism and not related to the physics of the situation. Option (B) is incorrect because the question states that the ball is made of plastic, not iron. Option (D) is irrelevant to the situation because the size of the ball does not affect its movement in this case, it is the forces acting on it that determine its motion.

According to Newton's third law of motion, for every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction. So, the forces that Tom and Bill are exerting on the ball are cancelling each other out, and the ball remains in one place. Option (A) is incorrect because the ball's behavior is not related to being stubborn. Option (B) is incorrect because the ball being made of iron or its size is not the reason why it stays in one place. Option (D) is also incorrect because the ball's size does not determine its ability to stay in one place when equal and opposite forces are applied to it.

Option (A) is incorrect because the ball's behavior is not attributed to being stubborn.
